pli-tv-bu-vb-np9:0.2: The monks’ rules and their analysis
pli-tv-bu-vb-np9:0.5: 9. The second training rule on what is set aside
pli-tv-bu-vb-np9:1.1: At one time the Buddha was staying at Sāvatthī in the Jeta Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s Monastery.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np9:1.2: At that time a certain man said to another man,
pli-tv-bu-vb-np9:1.3: “I“ll give a robe to Venerable Upananda.”
pli-tv-bu-vb-np9:1.5: “I, too, will give a robe to Venerable Upananda.”
pli-tv-bu-vb-np9:1.6: An alms-collecting monk heard that conversation.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np9:1.7: He then went to Upananda and said,
pli-tv-bu-vb-np9:1.9: In such-and-such a place I heard two men telling each other
pli-tv-bu-vb-np9:1.10: that they will each give you a robe.”
pli-tv-bu-vb-np9:1.14: Upananda then went to those men and said,
pli-tv-bu-vb-np9:1.15: “Is it true that you both desire to give me a robe?”
pli-tv-bu-vb-np9:1.17: that’s just what we were thinking.”
pli-tv-bu-vb-np9:1.18: “If that’s the case, then give me such-and-such a robe.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np9:1.19: For what’s the point of giving robes that I won’t use?”
pli-tv-bu-vb-np9:1.20: Those men complained and criticized him,
pli-tv-bu-vb-np9:1.21: “These Sakyan ascetics have great desires; they are not content.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np9:1.22: It’s no easy matter to give them robes.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np9:1.23: How can Venerable Upananda approach us and specify the kind of robe he wants without first being invited?”
pli-tv-bu-vb-np9:1.24: The monks heard the complaints of those men,
pli-tv-bu-vb-np9:1.25: and the monks of few desires complained and criticized him,
pli-tv-bu-vb-np9:1.26: “How can Venerable Upananda approach householders and make a suggestion about a robe without first being invited?”
pli-tv-bu-vb-np9:1.27: After rebuking him in many ways, they told the Buddha. Soon afterwards he had the Sangha assembled and questioned Upananda:
pli-tv-bu-vb-np9:1.28: “Is it true, Upananda, that you acted like this?”
pli-tv-bu-vb-np9:1.32: “Foolish man, people who are not related don’t know what’s appropriate and what’s inappropriate in dealing with each other, what’s right and what’s wrong.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np9:1.33: And still you approached unrelated householders and specified the kind of robe you wanted without first being invited.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np9:1.34: This won’t give rise to confidence in those without it …
pli-tv-bu-vb-np9:1.35: And, monks, this training rule should be recited thus:
pli-tv-bu-vb-np9:1.36: ‘If two male or female householders have set aside separate robe funds for an unrelated monk, thinking,
pli-tv-bu-vb-np9:1.37: ‘With these separate robe funds we’ll buy separate robes and give them to monk so-and-so;’
pli-tv-bu-vb-np9:1.38: and if that monk, without first being invited, approaches them and specifies the kind of robe he wants, saying,
pli-tv-bu-vb-np9:1.39: ‘It would be good if you would put these separate robe funds together to buy such-and-such a robe and then give it to me,’
pli-tv-bu-vb-np9:1.40: and he does so because he wants something nice, he commits an offense entailing relinquishment and confession.’”
pli-tv-bu-vb-np9:1.42: for the benefit of a monk; making a monk the object of consideration, they desire to give to him.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np9:1.46: anyone who is not a descendant of one’s male ancestors going back seven generations, either on the mother’s side or on the father’s side.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np9:1.48: any men who live in a house.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np9:1.50: any women who live in a house.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np9:1.52: money, gold, pearls, gems, corals, crystals, cloth, thread, or cotton wool.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np9:1.54: with that which is at their disposal.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np9:1.60: the monk for whom the robe funds have been set aside.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np9:1.62: they have not said beforehand: “Venerable, what kind of robe do you need? What kind of robe can we buy for you?”
pli-tv-bu-vb-np9:1.64: having gone to their house or having gone wherever.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np9:1.65: Specifies the kind of robe he wants:
pli-tv-bu-vb-np9:1.66: please make it long or wide or closely woven or soft.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np9:1.68: that which is at their disposal.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np9:1.70: long or wide or closely woven or soft.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np9:1.76: two people supplying him with one robe.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np9:1.78: wanting something nice, wanting something expensive.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np9:1.79: If those householders buy a robe that is long, wide, closely woven, or soft because of his statement, then the effort constitutes wrong conduct.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np9:1.80: When he gets the robe, it becomes subject to relinquishment.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np9:1.81: The robe should be relinquished to a sangha, a group, or an individual.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np9:1.82: “And, monks, it should be relinquished in this way.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np9:1.83: (To be expanded as in [Relinquishment 1](pli-tv-bu-vb-np1:3.2.5--3.2.29), with appropriate substitutions.)
pli-tv-bu-vb-np9:1.84: ‘Venerables, this robe which I received after approaching unrelated householders and specifying the kind of robe I wanted without first being invited is to be relinquished.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np9:1.85: I relinquish it to the Sangha.’ …
pli-tv-bu-vb-np9:1.88: ‘I give this robe back to you.’”
pli-tv-bu-vb-np9:1.89: If the householders are unrelated and he perceives them as unrelated, and, without first being invited, he approaches them and specifies the kind of robe he wants, he commits an offense entailing relinquishment and confession.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np9:1.90: If the householders are unrelated, but he is unsure if they are, and, without first being invited, he approaches them and specifies the kind of robe he wants, he commits an offense entailing relinquishment and confession.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np9:1.91: If the householders are unrelated, but he perceives them as related, and, without first being invited, he approaches them and specifies the kind of robe he wants, he commits an offense entailing relinquishment and confession.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np9:1.92: If the householders are related, but he perceives them as unrelated, commits an offense of wrong conduct.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np9:1.93: If the householders are related, but he is unsure if they are, commits an offense of wrong conduct.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np9:1.94: If the householders are related and he perceives them as related, there is no offense.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np9:1.97: if it is from those who have given an invitation;
pli-tv-bu-vb-np9:1.98: if it is for the benefit of another;
pli-tv-bu-vb-np9:1.99: if it is by means of his own property;
pli-tv-bu-vb-np9:1.100: if the householders wish to buy something expensive, but he gets them to buy something inexpensive;
pli-tv-bu-vb-np9:1.102: if he is the first offender.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np9:1.103: The ninth rule, the second training rule on what is set aside, is finished.
